2.10.text: Hilaree: So many things went awry everyday.

4.77.text: It was a lot of hard work. And to get to base camp

8.41.text: when I think of all the times we almost threw in the towel,

27.06.text:
So, we made it to
base camp, which...

29.66.text:
felt like kind of
a huge accomplishment

33.00.text:
in of itself,
was to get to 13000 feet

36.14.text: to get out of the jungle.

38.07.text:
We all struggled
so hard individually,

46.38.text:
You know, we're all like pretty
much A-type personalities.

51.18.text:
rely on people who you
can't communicate with.

53.09.text:
Then, finally, you know, we,
we come out above all of this.

56.36.text:
And it was like
coming out from, like

58.09.text:
being pinned under
water or something.

60.19.text:
And all of a sudden
we could breathe.

61.89.text:
And we're like "Oh my Gosh,
we're, we're in our environment.

64.86.text:
We're where we can, you know
take control of our own destiny.

74.21.text: basically coming out of the jungle.

76.31.text: For us to come out of the jungle and see white snow and glaciers

80.98.text: was really an amazing time in the trip.

84.15.text:
But, we'd lost so many
days under town arrest

86.75.text:
and we'd lost so many days
trying to find porters that

89.66.text:
we were rushed and we were
stressed at this point.

92.56.text:
And at no point in those
30 days had we spent

94.66.text:
more than two nights
in any one place.

97.16.text:
Except for when we were in
Putao under town arrest.

99.70.text:
So we were hustling
and we were trying

101.73.text: to switch over all of our gear.

107.41.text:
The next day was Halloween.
And I remember this because

110.01.text:
I got on the satellite
phone and I called home.

114.28.text:
And I remember,
my kids asking me

120.62.text:
Because,
I'd put them in this bin

122.42.text:
and I'd forgotten
to tell my husband

123.66.text:
and they didn't know where
their Halloween costumes were.

125.96.text:
And so I'm like talking
on this phone, like

128.33.text:
directing him through the
house to find this bin

132.10.text:
And I was like
"This is so weird."

138.10.text:
you know,
he's seven at the time

140.17.text:
and he was having a really
hard time learning to read.

144.01.text:
And, he'd been working
on it really hard

146.15.text:
so he picked up his book and
read to me over the phone.

149.58.text: And, I mean I'm going to, yeah

151.32.text: like, it was, I was... crushed.

156.06.text:
So I had this going on
all at the same time.

158.96.text: That we're trying to turn around

162.19.text:
go through all of our gear
that we hadn't seen in weeks.

165.13.text:
And we had one day to do it
in, and that was Halloween

167.93.text:
and then the next day
we were climbing.

169.84.text: So, we started pulling out all of our food

172.04.text: and trying to divvy it up and we realized that

173.84.text:
we had actually lost a lot
of food along the way.

177.01.text: We hadn't cut it out as a way of

179.28.text:
cutting our bags or
anything like that.

181.31.text: But, we had lost snack bags

182.98.text:
and I think some of it
got left in villages.

186.75.text: We'd lost a lot of rice because

188.42.text:
there were military outposts
in some of these villages.

191.02.text:
And in order for us to
move through that village

194.26.text:
they essentially bribed
us out of bags of rice.

196.86.text:
So, we were losing some of these
food supplies along the way.

200.20.text:
And when we sat down and
sorted it out, we were like

202.00.text:
"Okay, we have enough
for eight days of food

205.74.text:
And if we really stretch it
out we've got ten days."

208.47.text:
But, that's taking
everything with us.

210.64.text:
That leaves us basically nothing
for 130 miles walking out

215.68.text:
after trying to climb
this mountain.

225.22.text: Cory: You know Mark and I looked and we thought

227.99.text: you know, we should go this way

229.76.text: avoid some of the technicality of the lower ridge.

232.97.text: And Hilaree thought we should go another way.

235.73.text: Hilaree: Even just from the get go trying to pick out camp one

249.38.text: Hilaree had made the right call for camp one.

252.49.text: It's just hard making these decisions so far out there.

259.33.text: Renan: Big day. Going up a giant couloir

261.89.text: with technical climbing with heavy packs.

269.17.text: Emily: People were kind of just like, this is real, it's serious.

274.41.text: I was just right there with everyone else.

277.64.text:
A lot of the things that I did
today I've never done before.

281.15.text:
Cory: Kinda sketchy some
of it too, right?

284.68.text:
You are going up 55 degrees,
60 degree ice slope.

309.17.text: Hilaree: This mountain is full of surprises.

312.95.text: We have followed yet another dead end.

316.92.text: So, we have to backtrack an hour

321.29.text: Then do some steep snow and ridge climbing.

330.43.text: In reality, the peak was, like

333.83.text:
this Alpine version
of the jungle.

336.47.text:
It was up and down.
There was no straight way.

340.24.text: We kept having dead ends, uh...

345.61.text:
I think, as a team we became
really focused on climbing.

349.28.text:
But, we sort of lost
that team dynamic.

351.98.text:
We stopped focusing
on each other

353.65.text:
and how... the team was
gonna get to the summit.

357.69.text: This was our second day out of base camp.

361.09.text: And we were already in this crazy Alpine environment.

364.40.text: And that second day we reached a dead end.

367.07.text:
We had to come back
down to camp one.

369.13.text:
And then start day
three over again.

372.24.text:
And, I think it was
a really kind of...

377.24.text:
rude awakening for
all of us that

379.35.text:
the mountain wasn't going
to be this sanctuary.

382.28.text:
This place... that
we would un-map

386.92.text:
and magically arrive
at the summit.

388.79.text:
It was going to be
a lot of hard work

390.82.text:
and we were very
thin on resources.

394.79.text: Right here, we're basically standing on

399.83.text:
And... we were just on
our second dead end

404.74.text:
And trying to figure
out our route.

409.51.text: It was pretty windy, it was a little bit colder.

411.91.text:
I was definitely
missing the down pants

414.11.text:
that I'd left,
like at 2,000 feet

416.15.text:
in the jungle,
like three weeks earlier.

417.92.text:
The big, like 8,000 meter
boots that we didn't bring

421.19.text:
and opted for like the
smaller lighter boots.

423.86.text: This is Emily and I on the face.

425.62.text: And so I know that this probably like, a total news flash.

428.79.text:
But, men and women
are different.

433.87.text:
We have a different
way of communicating.

437.44.text:
Emily was definitely my
choice to bring on this trip.

439.91.text:
And she was really green in
this kind of environment.

442.78.text:
But, I had the
utmost faith in her.

445.41.text:
And she's so strong,
but she's emotional

448.21.text:
and she was nervous
on a lot of this.

450.32.text:
And so, I chose to kind of like
hang back and climb with her.

454.29.text:
And on this particular
face I had been in front

456.79.text:
and I stopped and I waited
for Cory and Emily to pass.

459.29.text:
And I hung back behind
and climbed below her.

461.69.text: And just, hung out with her.

463.10.text:
Plus, she's really funny
and she's super fun

466.60.text:
But I think as we were moving up
towards the summit

469.00.text:
that was sort of
perceived as a weakness

471.00.text: with the rest of the team.

474.14.text: women talk about things a lot more than men.

476.48.text: And when you get on a big mountain

478.74.text: sometimes the guys just weren't talking at all.

481.28.text:
And Emily and I were like,
"My toes are cold."

484.08.text:
Or "How are you layering? Are
you putting that under this?"

487.49.text:
And "Are you going to
wear your balaclava

488.85.text:
under your hat or
over your hat?"

490.92.text:
We were like,
talking about all these things

493.53.text:
that like,
girls talk about like, um...

496.23.text:
I don't know, like "You put
your hands in your armpits

499.13.text:
or down your pants
to keep warm."

501.03.text:
And um, I think that was also
like, our kind of chattiness

505.07.text:
and like, "Check my harness"
and "How does my anchor look?"

508.64.text:
was again sort of this second
tick against both of us.

514.78.text:
again was sort of perceived as
like another weakness

518.12.text:
as we were moving
up the mountain.

519.55.text: When we got to this face it was just sort of assumed that

522.59.text: one of the guys was going to lead the face

525.46.text: Like "I'm... I want to climb. I want to lead this face."

527.66.text:
And it was the first sense
I kind of got where, like

531.30.text:
there's a division
going on here.

533.23.text:
Where the girls are
in this corner

534.43.text: and the guys are in this corner.

536.14.text:
And, in the end
I did lead the face.

538.84.text:
And it was fine, and this
led to our high camp

544.28.text:
And we were six days into
the climb at this point.
